Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: New Biophotonics and Computational Molecular Dynamics for Understanding Epigenetic Regulation of Gene Transcription

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
ABSTRACT

#1249311
Backman, Vadim

This proposal aims to understand biological processes at the nanoscale that has been stymied by a lack of practical means of analysis of cellular nanoscale architecture. Conventional visible-light microscopy allows detection of morphological changes only at the micro-scale. To address this limitation, the PI?s have developed PWS microscopy, which quantifies the statistical properties of cellular nanoarchitecture. Using PWS, they demonstrated an increase in the disorder of nuclear nanoarchitecture in the earliest stages of carcinogenesis manifested as an alteration of the higher-order chromatin structure. This phenomenon was observed in multiple cancer types (lung, colon, pancreatic, esophageal, ovarian and thyroid cancers). This project will lead to the development of a new light-scattering interference-based microscopy technique, molecular PWS (mPWS) microscopy, which would allow molecular-specific sensing of cell chromatin structure at the nanoscale, which is not otherwise possible. The technique will be used to study epigenetic mechanisms of how changes in higher order chromatin structure modulate gene transcription. The proposed work is aimed at describing all these different processes related to the changes in the chromatin nanoenvironment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Chromatin is one of the most critical structures within the cell because it houses all genetic information. The higher-order organization of chromatin structure is crucial to gene regulation, and its dysregulation is a hallmark of many cellular pathological processes including carcinogenesis and chronic inflammation. Chromatin structure is well understood at the nucleosomal level (<20nm) and at the chromosomal level (>200nm). However, little is known about the higher-order chromatin structure between these length scales, how it regulates gene expression and its alterations in disease such as cancer. A key reason why we know so little about higher order chromatin structure is the lack of proper imaging and quantitative modalities to understand the structure and function of this organization, particularly in live cells. We have developed a new technique, backscattering interference spectroscopic (BASIS) microscopy, with sensitivity to structures between 20-200 nm that can quantify the nanoscale organization in live cells without using exogenous labels. We have also developed new approaches that incorporate the physical nanoenvironment of the cell nucleus into systems-level models of gene regulation. We have studied the effects of macromolecular crowding on processes occurring during transcriptional regulation.

Broader Impact: Alterations of global gene expression is a common etiology of some of the major diseases including cancer, atherosclerosis, and Alzheimer. On the other hand, a global alteration in gene expression would not be feasible without a change in chromatin nanoenvironment. The experimental and computational technologies developed in the course of the project may help develop diagnostic and therapeutic strategies against these diseases.
